edge: Shrek is an embittered ogre who lives in a swamp.
Lord Farquaad is the obsessive ruler mentioned in the context who banished fairy tale creatures to Shrek's swamp.
Princess Fiona is the person for whom Shrek makes a pact with Lord Farquaad in exchange for regaining control of his swamp.
Donkey is a talking donkey who helps Shrek in rescuing Princess Fiona.
The context mentions that the fairy tale creatures were banished to Shrek's swamp by Lord Farquaad.

Shrek makes a pact with Lord Farquaad to rescue Princess Fiona.

Cameron Diaz plays the role of Princess Fiona in the movie.
John Lithgow plays the role of Lord Farquaad in the movie.
Andrew Adamson is one of the directors of the movie Shrek.
Vicky Jenson is one of the directors of the movie Shrek.

After purchasing the rights to Steig's book in 1991, Steven Spielberg sought to produce a traditionally-animated film adaptation, but John H. Williams convinced him to bring the project to DreamWorks in 1994.
After purchasing the rights to Steig's book in 1991, Steven Spielberg sought to produce a traditionally-animated film adaptation.
In 1994, John H. Williams convinced Steven Spielberg to bring the project to DreamWorks.
Along with Williams and Aron Warner, Jeffrey Katzenberg began development on Shrek in 1995.
Chris Farley was cast as the voice for the title character, recording most of the required dialogue.
After the death of Chris Farley in 1997, Mike Myers was hired to replace him as the voice for Shrek.
The film parodies other fairy tale adaptations, primarily animated Disney films.
Initially intended to be created using motion capture, the studio hired Pacific Data Images to complete the final computer animation after poor test results.

Shrek and Fiona have feelings for each other, but misunderstandings arise when Shrek overhears Fiona referring to herself as an 'ugly beast'.
Fiona is cursed to transform into an ogre at night and can only be transformed back to her true form by 'true love's kiss'.
Donkey is a loyal friend of Shrek, but also scolds him for his bad behavior towards Fiona.
Fiona takes shelter in Duloc and later accepts Farquaad's marriage proposal there.
Donkey befriends the Dragon during his travels.

Shrek interrupts the wedding just before the ceremony ends, and tells Fiona that Farquaad is only marrying her to become king. The sun sets as Fiona transforms into an ogre in front of everyone, causing Shrek to understand Fiona's previous remarks.

Outraged and disgusted, Farquaad orders Shrek executed and Fiona re-imprisoned, so that he will still be king by technicality. The two are saved when the Dragon, ridden by Donkey, breaks in and devours Farquaad.
Shrek and Fiona profess their love and share a kiss. Fiona's curse is broken; she is surprised to find she has remained an ogre, though Shrek reassures her that he still finds her beautiful.
Shrek interrupts the wedding just before the ceremony ends, and tells Fiona that Farquaad is only marrying her to become king.
Fiona transforms into an ogre in front of everyone, causing Shrek to understand Fiona's previous remarks.

The Dragon, ridden by Donkey, breaks in and devours Farquaad.

At the time DreamWorks Pictures was founded, producer John H. Williams got hold of the book from his children and when he brought it to DreamWorks, it caught CEO Jeffrey Katzenberg's attention and the studio decided to make it into a film.

Upon our second reading of Shrek, the kindergartner started quoting large segments of the book pretending he could read them. Even as an adult, I thought Shrek was outrageous, irreverent, iconoclastic, gross, and just a lot of fun.

Steven Spielberg had thought about making a traditionally animated film adaptation of the book before, when he bought the rights to the book in 1991 where Bill Murray would play Shrek and Steve Martin would play Donkey,

In the early sketches of Shrek's house, which were created between 1996 and 1997 using Photoshop, it was depicted that Shrek initially resided in a garbage dump near a human village called Wart Creek.
At one point in time, it was assumed that Shrek would live with his parents and keep rotting fish in his bedroom.
Donkey was modeled after a real miniature donkey named Pericles (born 1994; also known as Perry) from Barron Park in Palo Alto, California.

In the early development stages, Fiona was not based on any real person. The supervising animator of Shrek, Raman Hui, created over 100 sculptures of Fiona before the directors selected the final design.

node_2: hearst castle, stratford upon avon, and dordogne
edge: During their visits to Hearst Castle, Stratford upon Avon, and Dordogne, the art directors drew inspiration for Shrek's swamp.
When an actor is offered a role to play an ogre in a movie, their decision to accept or decline may affect how children perceive them as a result of the physical transformation through animation.
Shrek is an ogre, which sets him apart from other characters in traditional fairy tales and challenges societal norms surrounding appearance and acceptance.
As the story crew developed the plot, they ensured that the main characters' personalities remained consistent to preserve the thematic unity of the story.
They centered the four main characters’ personalities on maladaptive responses to self-esteem issues.

Initially hired to voice Shrek, Chris Farley recorded nearly all of the dialogue for the character before his untimely death. After his passing, his brother was asked to finish his lines but refused. DreamWorks then re-casted the role to Mike Myers, who insisted on a complete script rewrite to avoid any traces of Farley's version.
Mike Myers voiced the character Shrek because he wanted the opportunity to work with Jeffrey Katzenberg and believed that the story of accepting oneself is a great one.

In 2000, after providing the voice for the character in 1999, Myers asked to re-record all of his lines with a Scottish accent similar to that used by his mother in bedtime stories. This decision led to more ideas and fresher gags, which improved the movie according to Spielberg. The cost of this request was disputed by Myers.

node_2: lothar of the hill people accent
edge: In 2000, after providing the voice for the character in 1999, Myers also tried using a Lothar of the Hill People accent while re-recording his lines. This decision is mentioned on the DVD commentary.
In 2000, after providing the voice for the character in 1999, Myers also tried using a Canadian accent while re-recording his lines. This decision is mentioned on the DVD commentary.

Initially, Shrek was set up to be a live-action/CG animation hybrid with background plate miniature sets and the main characters composited into the scene as motion-captured computer graphics using an ExpertVision Hires Falcon 10 camera system. However, after a year and a half of R & D, a sizable crew screened the results in May 1997, which were not satisfactory, with Katzenberg stating that 'It looked terrible, it didn't work, it wasn't funny, and we didn't like it.'

After the initial attempt at live-action/CG animation hybrid was not satisfactory, Shrek eventually got to its final, computer-animated look with production partners Pacific Data Images (PDI) beginning production in 1998.
Effects supervisor Ken Bielenberg was asked by Aron Warner to start development for Shrek while Antz was still in production at the studio.
PDI used its own proprietary software, like the Fluid Animation System, for most of its animated movies while working on Shrek with DreamWorks.

However, PDI also took advantage of some of the powerhouse animation software on the market, like Maya, for some elements, particularly for most of its dynamic cloth animation and for the hair of Fiona and Farquaad.

The animation team applied the facial system from Antz to Shrek's whole body, allowing for detailed movements such as forming a double chin when he opens his jaw due to the fat and muscles underneath.

The animation team worked on making Donkey's fur flow smoothly so that it did not look like a Chia pet's, using complex flow controls within a shader and environment condition reactivity by the visual effects group.
Making human hair realistic required a separate rendering system and much attention from the lighting and visual effects teams.

The film used pop music and other oldies to make the story more forward.
Katzenberg suggested to the filmmakers to redo the film's ending to "go out with a big laugh"
Rufus Wainwright suggested that his version of "Hallelujah" did not appear in the film due to the "glass ceiling" he was hitting because of his sexuality.
Although Rufus Wainwright's version of the song "Hallelujah" appeared in the soundtrack album, it was John Cale's version that appeared in the film;
because Wainwright was an artist for DreamWorks but Cale was not.
The film's 1996 animation test used the song "I Got You (I Feel Good)". The clip was considered lost until 2023.
The film's 1996 animation test used the song 'I Got You (I Feel Good)'.
When Tinker Bell falls on Donkey and he says "I can fly" and people around including the Three Little Pigs say "He can fly, he can fly"; this is a reference to Disney's Peter Pan.
The people around also say "He can fly, he can fly" when Tinker Bell falls on Donkey and says "I can fly"
The Three Little Pigs also say "He can fly, he can fly" when Tinker Bell falls on Donkey and says "I can fly"
While still flying, Donkey says "You might have seen a house fly, maybe even a super fly, but I bet you ain't never seen a Donkey fly!"
When Fiona is singing to the blue bird, it references Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.
When Shrek crosses the bridge to the Castle and says, "That'll do, Donkey, that'll do", this is a reference to the movie Babe.
When Princess Fiona is fighting the Merry Men, it's a lengthy reference to the film The Matrix.
At the end of the film, the Gingerbread Man at the end with a crutch (and one leg) says "God bless us, everyone" which is a reference to Tiny Tim in A Christmas Carol.

DreamWorks was so impressed by the technology used for the bar sequence in Antz's 'stereoscopic translation' that the studio and IMAX decided to plan a big-screen 3D version of Shrek

The film would have been re-released during the Christmas season of 2001, or the following summer, after its conventional 2D release. DreamWorks and IMAX decided to plan a big-screen 3D version of Shrek. Plans for this were dropped due to 'creative changes' instituted by DreamWorks and resulted in a loss of $1.18 million.
The Walt Disney Company asked Radio Disney not to promote the new release Shrek. This restriction was later relaxed for ads of the soundtrack album.
In 2001, Burger King began promotions for the film by giving out exclusive Candy Caddies based on the Shrek characters.
In 2001, Baskin-Robbins ran an 8-week promotion of the film, selling products such as Shrek's Hot Sludge Sundae and Shrek Freeze Frame Cake.
Shrek was released by DreamWorks Home Entertainment on VHS and DVD.
Another 4.5 million copies of Shrek were sold on VHS in the same timespan, making it the biggest opening weekend in retail video since The Lion King in 1995.

Shrek was released by DreamWorks Home Entertainment on VHS and DVD. It surpassed Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace's record for being the fastest-selling DVD ever, selling 2.5 million copies within the first three days of release.

node_1: shrek in the swamp karaoke dance party
edge: Both releases included Shrek in the Swamp Karaoke Dance Party, a 3-minute musical short film, that takes up right after Shrek's ending, with film's characters performing a medley of modern pop songs.

node_2: highest-grossing animated film ever to be released in australia
edge: Shrek became the highest-grossing animated film ever to be released in Australia, passing the mark set by The Lion King in 1994.
Shrek received wide critical acclaim and was an instant box office success.
Shrek received wide critical acclaim.
While simultaneously embracing and subverting fairy tales, the irreverent Shrek also manages to tweak Disney's nose
Shrek provides a moral message to children.
Shrek was beaten out by Lara Croft: Tomb Raider
Steven Rosen wrote about how DreamWorks Pictures proved to be a name that could be trusted for imaginative and funny animated movies that delight both kids and adults equally.
Steven Rosen's article in The Denver Post talked about how DreamWorks Pictures created movies that were imaginative and funny, delighting both kids and adults equally.

Susan Stark wrote a review for The Detroit News, giving the movie four out of four stars and stating that it was swift, sweet, irreverent, rangy, and as spirited in writing and voice work as it was splendid in design.
Susan Stark's review for The Detroit News praised DreamWorks Pictures for creating a movie that delighted audiences equally, as she gave it four out of four stars.

Jami Bernard from the New York Daily News gave Shrek four out of four stars, stating that it was an adorable and infectious work of true sophistication due to its brilliance in voice work, script, direction, and animation.
Rene Rodriguez called Shrek 'a gleefully fractured fairy tale that never becomes cynical or crass'.
Elvis Mitchell from The New York Times gave Shrek four out of five stars, stating that it beat up on the irritatingly dainty Disney trademarks with a demolition-derby zest.

William Steig, author of the original book and his wife Jeanne Steig, expressed their enjoyment for Shrek, saying that they expected to hate it but instead loved it as they thought it did a wonderful and witty job.

Mark Caro compared the film to Toy Story 2, saying that Toy Story 2 'had a higher in-jokes/laughs ratio without straining to demonstrate its hipness or to evoke heartfelt emotions' and Shrek was also an 'onslaught of in-jokes'
Michael Atkinson said he was 'desperately avoiding the risk of even a half-second of boredom' while reviewing Shrek

Mark Caro compared Shrek to Toy Story 2, saying that 'Toy Story 2 had a higher in-jokes/laughs ratio without straining to demonstrate its hipness or to evoke heartfelt emotions' and Shrek 'strives to have a heart'
Anthony Lane said, despite the film 'cunningly rendering of surfaces', there's still something 'flat and charmless in the digital look' for Shrek

node_2: message about beauty coming from within
edge: Christy Lemire said, while Shrek 'strives to have a heart' and has 'a message about beauty coming from within', 'somehow [the message] rings hollow'
Anthony Lane said most of the pleasure in Shrek rose 'not from the main romance but from the quick, incidental gags'

In June 2008, the American Film Institute revealed its 'Ten top Ten'; the best ten films in ten 'classic' American film genres - after polling over 1,500 people from the creative community Shrek was acknowledged as the eighth best film in the animated genre, and the only non-Disney·Pixar film in the Top 10.

In November 2009, the character, Lord Farquaad, was listed No. 14 in IGN UK's 'Top 15 Fantasy Villains'. In 2005, Shrek came sixth in Channel 4's '100 Greatest Family Films' poll behind The Simpsons, Tom and Jerry, South Park, Toy Story and Family Guy.
In 2006, it was ranked third on Bravo's '100 funniest films' list.

Shrek had a significant impact that influenced a later generation of mainstream animated films, such as Robots, Chicken Little, Doogal, Ron's Gone Wrong and more recently with Ruby Gillman: Teenage Kraken and The Tiger’s Apprentice.

node_2: computer animated films spoofing fairy tales
edge: Such elements can be seen in films like Chicken Little, Happily N'Ever After, Igor, Hoodwinked!, Enchanted and its sequel Disenchanted.
Fractured Fairy Tales and The Princess Bride have parodied the traditional fairy tale, influenced by Shrek's success.

node_2: pop culture references and end-film musical numbers
edge: Such elements can be seen in films like Robots, Chicken Little, Doogal, Ron's Gone Wrong and more recently with Ruby Gillman: Teenage Kraken and The Tiger’s Apprentice. This trend was popularized by Shrek 2.
The New York Times retrospectively described the film as 'a beloved, offbeat fairy tale whose characters and jokes continue to permeate pop culture, reaching another generation of fans.'

node_2: recipient of national film registry preservation
edge: In 2020, the United States Library of Congress selected Shrek to be preserved in the National Film Registry for being 'culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant'.

node_2: video game adaptations of the film
edge: Several video game adaptations of the film have been published on various game console platforms, including Shrek (2001), Shrek: Hassle at the Castle (2002), Shrek: Extra Large (2002), Shrek: Super Party (2002) and Shrek SuperSlam (2005).
Shrek was also included as a bonus unlockable character in the video game Tony Hawk's Underground 2 (2004).
A musical version, based on the film, was created.
The musical version of Shrek opened on Broadway on December 14, 2008.
A London production of the musical version of Shrek opened in the West End on June 7, 2011.
In 2003, Dark Horse Comics released a three-issue mini-series comic book adaptation of Shrek.
A shot-for-shot fan remake titled Shrek Retold was released through 3GI Industries on November 29, 2018.
The project was a collaboration of 200 filmmakers.
The film is available on YouTube for free.
A shot-for-shot fan remake titled Shrek Retold was released through 3GI Industries on November 29, 2018.

The project was a collaboration of 200 filmmakers and mixes live action, hand drawn animation, Flash animation, CGI and various other art forms to recreate the film. The film is available on YouTube for free.[160][161]
The three sequels, Shrek 2, Shrek the Third, and Shrek Forever After, were released over the years.
Shrek 2 received similar acclaim from critics as the original movie.
All three sequels were commercially successful.
Centered on the titular character's life before his debut in Shrek 2.

Tasked to reboot both Shrek and Puss in Boots, with the original cast potentially returning to reprise their roles.
On November 6, 2018, Variety reported that Chris Meledandri had been tasked to reboot both Shrek and Puss in Boots.
Development stalled, and future plans have yet to be officially announced.
The statement 'a fifth Shrek film' refers to a planned sequel in the Shrek franchise, which was reported in April 2023.
The statement 'with the original cast' refers to the fact that the planned fifth Shrek film will feature the same voice actors as the previous films in the series.
In June 2024, Eddie Murphy (Murphy) announced that he had already begun recording voice sessions for Shrek, which indicates his involvement in the fifth installment of the Shrek franchise.
Murphy also mentioned that he would begin working on the Donkey spinoff once it was completed, suggesting a possible connection between Shrek and the upcoming spinoff featuring Donkey.
The statement 'in April 2023' indicates that the news about a fifth Shrek film was reported during this month.
The statement 'in June 2024' reveals that Eddie Murphy made a statement regarding his involvement in the fifth Shrek film during this month.
